documents.title: that 's it ! thank you for all your questions
text: guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 4:14pm thank you so much , this has been an invigorating and enlightening discussion .
i must do it more often !
bingotango writes : it is quite apparent that there is a gap between - let 's call it roughly , those who can read music and those who do n't .

continuing to ignore music development in schools also maintains a socially divisive and elite /pop split that of course feeds directly in to commerce , the recording industry , musical theatre , concert circuit , etc .
but surely as culture minister you should have some responsibility for just that .
is your emphasis too fiscal , and if so why ?
to profit those concerned or for social engineering ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 4:15pm to your second question , quite possibly .
i 'll look into this after the election .
we have funded music education centrally in order to secure music education in schools .

but we 've also funded in harmony which does some amazing work in important parts of the country , but also through the arts council we fund a huge range of music projects , particulary at kids who may have been let down by the education system .
music is for everyone and i think lots of kids have lots of accessibility to lots of kinds of music .
i do think that the classical music world does need to work as hard as possible to make sure that they can bring in new audiences who might find it intimidating .
by much greater informality .

documents.title: `` i once answered a parliamentary question about one direction using their song titles ''
text: jenny stevens asks : how do you feel about zayn ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 4:09pm i once answered a parliamentary question about one direction when i inserted several song titles from this great band .
the next day the sun replaced zayn 's face with my head .
is this an omen ?
but to be serious , one direction have been a phenomenal success , a great british export , and i wish zayn all the luck in the world .

documents.title: `` which shakespearian character would i play ? falstaff . he seems to enjoy himself ``
text: mypetspider asks : if you could play any one shakespearian character , who would it be ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 4:08pm falstaff .
he seems to enjoy himself .
or perhaps dromeo from the comedy of errors which is my favourite shakespeare play .

chris skirving asks : as a champion of the video games industry and with rockstars bringing in over one billion from their latest release grand theft auto v , how would you provide incentive for small game studios to grow and reach their potential ?

guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 4:07pm well , we 've introduced the video games tax credit which will benefit more sizeable games , but by sustaining the video games community that will benefit smaller developers .
but the chancellor also announced he was going to fund the abatery development fund which funds small developers , and creative england is also a financial supporter of the games industry .
wartypig asks : i recently came across an article that claims that modern art was cia 'weapon '' .
does politics influence art or is it the case that art influence politics ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 4:05pm clearly there 's a kind of relationship between politics and art .
and art is often at its best when it commentates on the political climate of the day .
and i think art provides an opportunity for people to express their views and it can often be a very powerful weapon .
particularly for people living under oppressive regimes .
in the uk , government itself tries to draw a line , and although it allocates taxpayer money to arts organisations , it does not and should not influence what they produce .
but artists are powerful and they can shape the climate of our time .

documents.title: `` the idea that arts subjects have been cut in state schools is a myth ''
text: sisyphusow asks : how will the tories protect arts education in state schools ?
arts subjects have often been hit the worst in schools suffering from funding cuts and attempting to hit targets for performance in more academic subjects .
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:57pm well , again this is another myth .
if you look at the number of arts subjects being studied compared with science , arts outnumber them significantly .
music and arts remain part of the nation curriculum and we secured a great deal to continue to fund musical education from the centre .
we 've pursued a number of other initiatives like heritage schools , and into film , and so i 'm confident that arts education in schools will continue to thrive .
totalbigot asks : does the relative per capita expenditure on the arts in london compared with the rest of the country strike you as equitable ?
do you have any plans to change this ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:55pm this is a long running argument .

to a certain extent i reject part of the premise of the argument because there are lots of arts organisations with london postcodes who actually do work all across the uk - so simply basing it on these crude statistics does n't give the real but in any event , more money is now going out of london than before and the arts council have certainly said it 's a problem they want to address .

i also think initiatives like the 'northern powerhouse ' and the focus on devolving power down to cities should include more opportunities for areas outside london to fund their own culture institutions .
i think the northern powerhouse , what osborne is trying to achieve is real devolution of power to key northern cities .

that includes the 70m that is going to the factory in manchester , and so when one is thinking about these issues you think about transport , and business investment , but you should also be thinking about cultural investment as well .
look at liverpool as the european city of culture , the manchester international festival , you see cities looking at culture as forming their identity in the 21st century .
and so when you look at them when determining their autonomy for the future , culture has to be part of that discussion .
rainborough asks : a media landscape dominated by extremely rich individuals and big corporations , along with a bbc wholly outside control by licence payers , is an affront to democracy .
it serves only to reinforce the power of the dominant class . ''
discuss guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:50pm i would n't agree with that analysis .
the rise of technology has brought much greater democracy .
although youtube is owned by a big corporation the opportunity for the likes of jamal edwards for example to create their own media is far greater than it 's ever been .
but i slightly echo my last answer by recognising that the media has a special place in our society , and therefore has to work very hard to ensure that it reflects our society as it is today .
assistantdirector asks : there are a lot of production companies getting away with no pay , or expenses only jobs .

as someone who works in the media industry , how are we expected to live off expenses only , and since the industry seems to be only for privately schooled middle/upper classes , what happens to those of us who are talented but are not being given a fair chance ?
how do you plan to address the inequality and make the industry fair for all ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:49pm i think you touch on a very live issue .
the industry has come together with creative skillset to fund job opportunities .
a consortium led by channel 4 has brought in about 400 organisations to fund internships and apprenticeships .
i also want to see real change on the diversity of gender where we see far more talented people from the bame community have their chance to work in the film and television industries .

but i think we need to return to this subject after the election and do a proper analysis on the kind of people who are getting opportunities in the industry , and on the working practices some companies adopt .

gwig asks : arts and culture accounts for 0.7 percent of public funding ( or 0.1 , according to some sources ) , and delivers a positive return on that investment my question is , if the arts and culture sector generates a positive impact on the economy from the ( comparatively small ) public funding it receives , why has the conservative party chosen to reduce investment while in office , when economic growth was a declared mission for this government ?

guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:46pm well i agree that the arts make an important economic contribution , but it 's also important to see their intrinsic value and not see them as a economic instrument .

we had to make cuts across the board , and it would have been impossible to argue for the arts to be exempt , although people may not agree with my approach i did try to make in `` smart cuts '' by ensuring that we ringfenced as much as possible the money that goes directly to arts organisation .
we also substantially increased lottery funding and if you look at the combined grant in aid and lottery funding it 's about the same as the last parliament .
we have introduced tax credits for orchestra and theatre as well , and also secured funding for music education .
clareyesno asks : you 're responsible for looking after and nurturing the creative industries in this country and you 're involved in business , skills and innovation .
how do you avoid art being merely a commercial enterprise ?

should strong public funding of the arts prevent people having to make art that will necessarily appeal to a mass market , and are the tories going to strongly fund the arts if they win the next election ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:43pm yes there will continue to be public funding for the arts - the level will be decided in the next spending round .
but i am absolutely committed to public funding as an essential part of arts funding .

second i do n't necessarily agree that commercial sponsorship compromises the arts , i think that any intelligent commercial sponsor would see it as self defeating to influence the content of shows and as far as individual philanthropists are concerned , most arts organisations would realise they are passionate friends and partners .
it 's worth reminding people that a lot of commercial leaders in the creative industries do understand the importance of the subsidised arts .
and you will see the greatest advocates of both public funding and arts education coming from the private sector .

people like ian livingstone for video games , or those in film tv and west end theatres all realise this symbiotic relationship and realise they could n't be commercially successful without the publicly funded arts sector .

documents.title: `` the last film that moved me ? whiplash and paddington ''
text: clareyesno asks : what was the last film/song/play/show etc to really move you ?
as in almost or actually cry ?
guardian contributor edvaizey1 26 march 2015 3:40pm oh my god !
well , i think the one that 's moved me the most emotionally was probably whiplash .
in the sense of feeling fully immersed and caught up in it .
and shouting out during the screening , in disbelief and horror .
but i was also moved by paddington , which is of course a great british movie .
i was moved to tears at the royal court quiz night when my team failed to win , which was clearly a fix .
the next play i 'm anticipating will move me emotionally is jonathan maitland 's dead sheep .

text: following labour 's chris bryant and ukip 's peter whittle , we 've reached the third in our pre-election webchats with the main parties ' culture heads .

while sajid javid is the chief culture minister for the conservatives , ed vaizey , as the minister for culture , communications and the creative industries '' , is one of the party 's most experienced arts-focused politicians .
vaizey worked as a lawyer and conservative speechwriter before being elected as an mp in the 2005 general election .
he became shadow minister for the arts until 2010 , and then continued to work in the culture department of the current government .

his job now sees him with a unique and important remit , with one foot in the culture department and the other in business , skills and innovation - well placed therefore to understand both the creative and financial challenges for artists of all stripes .

he joins us to discuss your questions about the tories ' plans for the arts , whether they win another term in office or not - from how best to nurture nationwide creativity , to his own tastes in music , film and more .
he joins us from 3.30pm on thursday 26 march , so post your questions in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as time allows .
